data.title: Concept Foundation
data.meta_description: Led by the Executive Director, our dedicated team comprises forward-thinking, qualified and highly experienced individuals at various levels, who bring diverse backgrounds, expertise and passion to achieve our strategic objectives.
data.text:
Metin Gülmezoglu completed his medical degree and qualified as an obstetrician and gynaecologist in Turkey. He then worked at the University of the Witwatersrand as a clinician and researcher in South Africa completing his PhD in 1996. Between 1996 and 1998 he worked at the National Perinatal Epidemiology Unit and UK Cochrane Centre in Oxford, UK.

In 1998, Metin joined the World Health Organization, Sexual and Reproductive Health and Research Department (includes the UNDP/UNFPA/UNICEF/WHO/World Bank Special Programme – HRP) where he worked until July 2019. He was the coordinator for maternal and perinatal health, safe abortion and research capacity strengthening at WHO.

Metin worked extensively on systematic reviews within and outside the Cochrane Collaboration, conducted large observational studies and randomized controlled trials in key interventions to improve maternal and perinatal health with over 350 peer-reviewed articles published. Metin is an honorary fellow of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists in the UK and honorary member of The Society for Maternal Fetal Medicine in the U.S.A.

Alessandra Fleurent studied Epidemiology at the Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute. After obtaining experience at several public health NGOs, she joined Concept Foundation in 2015 and since then, she has held several different roles in the organisation.

As a Programme Officer, she coordinated projects aimed at increasing the selection of quality-assured SRH technologies available for procurement, and collaborating directly with pharmaceutical manufacturers and laboratories. She now works as Programme Manager, coordinating the PEARLS trial, the largest ever trial study on use of aspirin to prevent pre-eclampsia.

Alessandra Tomazzini holds a BSc. in Pharmacy and is a postgraduate in both Quality Management and Quality Engineering. Alessandra has over 20 years’ experience in Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient (API) and Final Pharmaceutical Products (FPP) operations. She has managed projects such as plant start-up of both API and FPP sites for sterile, hormonal, cytotoxic drugs in solid, semi-solid and liquid forms and has provided support for companies to obtain GMP certification.

As Head of Technical Services, she oversees the organisation’s technical activities relating to product development, transfer of technology and support to API and FPP manufacturers on GMP.

Anne Ammerdorffer has a BSc. and MSc. Biology from Wageningen University and obtained her PhD from the RadboudUMC, the Netherlands.

She worked several years as a scientist on Chlamydia-related bacteria, with a focus on immunology, female reproductive health and innovative Point-of-Care tests.

She coordinates clinical research projects and is responsible for the landscape analysis and finding new promising innovations in the field of reproductive and maternal health.

Jennifer Blum (M.P.H., UCLA) has two decades of experience in SRH. She is a substantive expert in reproductive health, with a deep technical understanding of the clinical aspects of family planning (FP) and SRH services. She has experience in designing and carrying out research to understand the safety, efficacy, and acceptability of reproductive and maternal health interventions. She has organized, facilitated, and designed content for global workshops on SRH/FP.

Jennifer was previously the Vice President of Gynuity Health Projects, a not-for-profit research organization focused on reproductive and maternal health globally. She has also been a Program Officer at the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, where she oversaw grant making for investments in sub-Saharan Africa, and global youth initiatives. Earlier in her career, Jennifer was a Peace Corps Volunteer in the Republic of Guinea, in West Africa. Currently, she is a principal researcher at Mathematica.

Jennifer has co-authored 47 publications in peer-reviewed journals including The Lancet, Contraception, IJGO, and BJOG.

Jennifer Scott is a Physician Scientist who trained in Obstetrics and Gynecology and Global Women’s Health at Harvard Medical School and its affiliated hospitals. She received a Master of Public Health degree in Clinical Effectiveness from Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. She has worked in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center since 2011, including as Director of the Division of Global and Community Health.

Jennifer has experience as a clinician in development and humanitarian contexts, and in conducting mixed methods research. Her area of research expertise is in gender and gender-based violence, including designing and evaluating interventions. The studies have assessed how gender and social norms influence health and well-being, with the aim of strengthening maternal and reproductive health services. She has worked in collaboration with community-based organisations, national and international NGOs, academic institutions, government stakeholders, and multilateral organisations to address health and gender disparities through research, innovation, and policy.

Jennifer joined Concept Foundation in 2023 as Senior Project Coordinator. As Director, a.i. R&D, she is part of a multi-disciplinary team implementing the PEARLS trial, a randomised clinical trial in sub-Saharan Africa.

Carolin has over six years of experience in communications and knowledge management for WHO, with a specific focus on abortion, family planning, maternal health and female genital mutilation (FGM). For a local NGO in Sweden, she has also developed advocacy products that have been concretely reflected in new laws and policies to combat honour-based violence, child marriage and FGM. Furthermore, Carolin has experience from the private sector, having worked with sustainability reporting, market research, and supply chain for some of the world’s largest FMCG companies, including in menstrual hygiene, pharma, and design.

She holds a MSc. in marketing from Stockholm University, and a MSc. in Media Technology/Journalism from the Royal Institute of Technology, Sweden, and has also studied human rights and development in Switzerland and Australia.

As Communications Manager, she translates complex scientific information into captivating, digestible and relatable stories, to highlight Concept Foundation’s unique position in the SRH space, and how our projects translate into a real difference in the lives of women and girls.

Gilda Piaggio completed a degree in Agronomy in Uruguay, and both her MSc and PhD degrees in Statistics in Iowa State University, United States. She has worked as a statistician for the University of Campinas, Brazil, and for international organizations in Central America.

In 1994, Gilda joined the World Health Organization, where she was coordinator for the Statistics and Informatics Services unit at the Sexual and Reproductive Health and Research Department.

Between 2009 and 2017 she worked for the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, University of London, London, UK, in the Distance Learning Programme, and as Honorary Professor.

Gilda has worked as a statistician in clinical trials in contraceptive research, maternal and perinatal health and child health. She has also worked on the reporting of randomised trials as part of the CONSORT Collaboration, in particular on guidance for reporting non-inferiority and equivalence randomised trials and cluster randomised trials. She has been a member of data safety committees for many trials, and has over 100 articles published in peer-reviewed journals.

For Concept Foundation, Gilda is working on the implementation pilots analysis under the Postpartum Haemorrhage (PPH) project.

Peter Hall has worked in reproductive health for 60 years, starting as a post-graduate at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School, London. He worked for 26 years with WHO’s Department of Reproductive Health and Research in Geneva, managing its research and development programme on long-acting contraceptives and being Chief of its Unit on Technology Introduction and Transfer.

From 1998, he led the NGO Reproductive Health Alliance, and was instrumental in the establishment of the International Consortium on Emergency Contraception in 1995 and the International Consortium for Medical Abortion in 2002. He has also worked as an independent consultant for several international agencies.

Peter has worked for Concept Foundation since 2003 and was Chief Executive Officer at Concept Foundation between 2008 and 2014. He is also Adjunct Professor at the School of Women’s and Children’s Health, University of New South Wales (UNSW), Sydney.

Lester Chinery is Director, M&A, Business Development at Concept Foundation and Program Director for the Quality of Reproductive Health Medicines program.

Lester has over 20 years of senior level Reproductive Health/Family Planning experience working with Concept Foundation, the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) and its subsidiary company ICON Ltd, which he founded in 2000, serving as its Managing Director/IPPF Director of Procurement Services until 2008. Prior to that, Lester was Contraceptive Social Marketing Manager for the IPPF European Network, introducing a range of low-cost contraceptives across Eastern Europe in partnership with commercial manufacturers. He was IPPF’s first representative at the time of formation of the RHSC and served on the Executive Committee in 2006.

Petra studied Biomedical Sciences with Pharmacology followed by a Masters in Clinical Pharmacology, Drug Development and Biobusiness, at the University of Aberdeen. After her studies, she moved straight from a voluntary Internship at WHO in the Pharmacovigilance department to her first role at CF in 2011.

In her 12 years at CF, she has supported CF’s work on Quality of SRH medicines, Access to Family Planning, managing CF’s work on increasing access to Injectable Contraception before moving to Programme Manager of CF’s Manufacturing and Development programmatic pillar.

As Senior Programme Manager she now supports projects across CF’s programmatic pillars and thematic areas, bringing over a decade of knowledge and experience in access to Quality Assured SRH medicines and techologies in LMICs.

Wannaporn Tepraska earned her BSc. in Medical Technology from Chulalongkorn University and her MBA in Logistics Management from Ramkhamhaeng University. She also has a B.Acc from University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce.

She has experience in the field of clinical research of anti-malarial drugs, HIV and Tuberculosis, and she has worked as Laboratory Coordinator and Biobank Project Manager.

She is theGrants Administration Manager and supports the teams on payments, expense tracking and coordination of financial matters. She works closely with the Program Managers on budget monitoring and prepares project financial reports to be submitted to donors.
